title-group.article-title: Support for Aboriginal health services in reducing harms from alcohol: 2‚Äêyear service provision outcomes in a cluster randomized trial
title-group.alt-title: Reducing harms from alcohol: cluster RCT

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ License, which permits use, distribution and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited and is not used for commercial purposes.

sec.title: Background and aims
sec.p: There is a higher prevalence of unhealthy alcohol use among Indigenous populations, but there have been few studies of the effectiveness of screening and treatment in primary health care. Over 24‚Äâmonths, we tested whether a model of service‚Äêwide support could increase screening and any alcohol treatment.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Cluster‚Äêrandomized trial with 24‚Äêmonth implementation (12‚Äâmonths active, 12‚Äâmonths maintenance).

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Australian Aboriginal Community Controlled primary care services.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Twenty‚Äêtwo services (83‚Äâ032 clients) that use Communicare practice software and see at least 1000 clients annually, randomized to the treatment arm or control arm.

sec.title: Intervention and comparator
sec.p: Multi‚Äêfaceted early support model versus a comparator of waiting‚Äêlist control (11 services).

sec.title: Measurements
sec.p: A record (presence‚Äâ=‚Äâ1, absence‚Äâ=‚Äâ0) of: (i) Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test‚ÄîConsumption (AUDIT‚ÄêC) screening (primary outcome), (ii) any‚Äêtreatment and (iii) brief intervention. We received routinely collected practice data bimonthly over 3¬†years (1‚Äêyear baseline, 1‚Äêyear implementation, 1‚Äêyear maintenance). Multi‚Äêlevel logistic modelling was used to compare the odds of each outcome before and after implementation.

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: The odds of being screened within any 2‚Äêmonth reference period increased in both arms post‚Äêimplementation, but the increase was nearly eight times greater in early‚Äêsupport services [odds ratio (OR)‚Äâ=‚Äâ7.95, 95% confidence interval (CI)‚Äâ=‚Äâ4.04‚Äì15.63, P‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.001]. The change in odds of any treatment in early support was nearly double that of waiting‚Äêlist controls (OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.89, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.19‚Äì2.98, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.01) but was largely driven by decrease in controls. There was no clear evidence of difference between groups in the change in the odds of provision of brief intervention (OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.95, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.53‚Äì7.17, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.32).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An early support model designed to aid routine implementation of alcohol screening and treatment in Aboriginal health services resulted in improvement of Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test‚ÄîConsumption screening rates over 24‚Äâmonths of implementation, but the effect on treatment was less clear.

award-group.funding-source: Centre of Research Excellence in Indigenous Health and Alcohol

institution-wrap.institution: Australian National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC)

p.mixed-citation: DzidowskaM, LeeKSK, ConigraveJH, DobbinsTA, HummerstonB, WilsonS, et al. Support for Aboriginal health services in reducing harms from alcohol: 2‚Äêyear service provision outcomes in a cluster randomized trial. Addiction. 2022;117:796‚Äì803. 10.1111/add.15712 34605084

fn.p: Funding information Practitioner Fellowships, Grant/Award Numbers: ID#1155320, ID#1117582; Centre of Research Excellence in Indigenous Health and Alcohol, Grant/Award Number: ID# 1117198; Australian National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), Grant/Award Number: ID#1105339

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Indigenous peoples that have been colonized, including Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, are more affected by alcohol‚Äêrelated harms than general populations [1, 2, 3, 4]. Harms of colonization, including intergenerational trauma, combined with introduction of mass‚Äêproduced alcohol, underpin this disparity [5].

Regular screening for unhealthy alcohol use (drinking above recommended guidelines, including alcohol use disorders) is important for timely detection. Cost‚Äêeffective brief intervention (BI) can then be provided to those with unhealthy drinking who are not dependent [6]. Clients with dependence can be treated in primary care settings, including with pharmacotherapies or referred to specialist services, if appropriate.

Recent systematic reviews [7, 8] found only four studies of implementation strategies to increase the uptake of both screening and the full spectrum of treatment for unhealthy alcohol use [7]. While they consistently showed improvement in screening, their impact on treatment provision was variable. None were conducted in Australian or other Indigenous populations.

This report describes the outcomes of a cluster randomized trial to assess whether a service delivery support model, designed for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Community Controlled Health Services (ACCHS), can produce a sustained increase in uptake of screening and appropriate treatment for unhealthy alcohol use. The first 12‚Äâmonths (active phase) of support resulted in a significant increase in screening in any 2‚Äêmonth period over that time [odds ratio (OR)‚Äâ=‚Äâ5.52, 95% confidence interval (CI)‚Äâ=‚Äâ4.31‚Äì7.07] [9]. However, there was no significant increase in the odds of BI. That analysis did not assess provision of a broader spectrum of treatment.

Previous studies have shown that longer implementation was associated with better outcomes [10]. In this analysis we examine the effects of the support on screening and provision of alcohol treatment over the full 24‚Äâmonths of implementation (active and maintenance phases), and investigate if the effects of provision of BI over 24‚Äâmonths differed from 12‚Äêmonth results. We hypothesized that over the 24‚Äâmonths there would be an increase in the odds of: (i) screening; (ii) provision of any alcohol treatment; and (iii) provision of BI for unhealthy alcohol use.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: The full study protocol was retrospectively registered (ACTRN12618001892202) and published [9, 11]. This paper was prepared using the Consolidated Standards of Reporting‚ÄâTrial (CONSORT) extension for cluster randomized trials [12].

sec.title: Study design and recruitment
sec.p: The study is a cluster randomized trial of 22 ACCHS across Australia, with an equal allocation to treatment (early‚Äêsupport) and waiting‚Äêlist control arms. During recruitment there were approximately 140‚Äì143 ACCHS in Australia [13, 14]. Of these, 132 were assessed for eligibility. ACCHS were eligible if they: (i) used Communicare practice software; and (ii) provided care for 1000 or more unique clients per year.

sec.title: Sample size and randomization
sec.p: Sample size was calculated to detect 13% increase in treatment for unhealthy alcohol use, as this would require the larger sample than for screening alone (Supporting information, Section S1). Eleven ACCHS were recruited per arm [11]. Randomization of ACCHS, stratified by remoteness (based on the road distance to the nearest urban centre; Table¬†1) [15], was performed by the study statistician (TD) in SAS statistical software, using coded identifiers to ensure blinded allocation.

caption.p: Service characteristics by trial arm at the end of 12‚Äêmonth baseline period (52‚Äâ678 clients; 142‚Äâ519 observations).a

tr.td: Clients recorded as receiving treatment for UAUd (%)
Clients recorded as receiving brief intervention (%)

fn.p: Baseline period: from 29 August 2016 to 30 August 2017, inclusive;
An observation appeared in the data set for a client if they attended their service for a consultation in the preceding 2‚Äêmonth reference period at least once;
mean score among clients who had at least one recorded AUDIT‚ÄêC score;

UAU‚Äâ=‚Äâunhealthy alcohol use; treatment as recorded in Communicare (i.e. advice recorded using selected clinical items or pharmacotherapies prescribed). SD‚Äâ=‚Äâstandard deviation; AUDIT‚ÄêC‚Äâ=¬†Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test‚ÄîConsumption.

sec.title: Implementation strategy
sec.p: The 24‚Äêmonth support model (Fig.¬†1) consisted of eight core components (Supporting information, Table S1) designed to aid routine implementation of alcohol screening and appropriate treatment. Support was delivered to the early‚Äêsupport arm services in two 12‚Äêmonth phases: active (components c1‚Äìc8) and maintenance (c4‚Äìc8). Waiting‚Äêlist control services operated as normal and had contact with the research team only when providing data. Following both phases in early support, the waiting‚Äêlist control arm received their support. Services received $AUD100 each as staff‚Äêtime reimbursement after each provision of data in phases when they were not receiving support.

caption.p: Graphic summary of the support model trialled during this study. c1 ‚Äì c8: eight components of the support model. Detailed description is provided in Supporting information, Table¬†S1. Implementation is considered as commencing on 31 August 2017, when service champions returned to their services following the workshop. Implementation ended on the last day of the final workshop on 15 August 2019

sec.title: Study outcomes
sec.p: We analysed data collected over 3‚Äâyears (12 months baseline, 24 months implementation). Services extracted de‚Äêidentified, routinely collected clinical data from their practice software, Communicare, using SQL commands every 2‚Äâmonths. Clients‚Äô records were matched through client IDs [11]. If a client attended in a 2‚Äêmonth period this resulted in an observation, which included age, gender and outcome variables.

The outcomes were a recording (yes/no) of each of the following in each 2‚Äêmonth period:
screening with the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test‚ÄîConsumption (AUDIT‚ÄêC); primary outcome (Supporting information, Section S2);
any treatment: advice/BI or counselling for unhealthy alcohol use or prescription of naltrexone, acamprosate or disulfiram; secondary outcome; and
BI: advice/BI for unhealthy alcohol use; secondary outcome.

sec.title: Analysis
sec.p:
We tested whether the support model improved the clients‚Äô odds of each outcome being recorded at least once in any 2‚Äêmonth period. To account for the effects of clustering by service and client, we used multi‚Äêlevel logistic modelling (‚Äòlme4‚Äô package [16] in R statistical software version 4.0.2 [17]). All models focused on testing the following fixed effects:
‚Äòcondition‚Äô: early support arm (condition‚Äâ=‚Äâ1); waiting‚Äêlist controls (condition‚Äâ=‚Äâ0);
‚Äòpost‚Äêimplementation‚Äô: whether an observation occurred on or after the start of implementation‚Äîtaken as the date when service champions returned from the national workshop, 31 August 2017 (yes‚Äâ=‚Äâ1, no‚Äâ=‚Äâ0); and
‚Äòintervention‚Äô: effect of support model, given by the interaction between ‚Äòcondition‚Äô and ‚Äòpost‚Äêimplementation‚Äô. Interaction represents relative change in the odds for the early support arm when compared to the waiting‚Äêlist controls, post‚Äêimplementation.We tested a range of random effects. Model selection is detailed in Supporting information, Sections S3 and S4. We calculated:
fixed effects and confidence intervals (Wald estimation);
changes in odds over time for the early support arm (simple slope analysis) using the delta method (‚Äòcar‚Äô package [18, 19]); and
adjusted intracluster correlation coefficients (ICC) to describe the proportion of variability explained by differences between clusters (‚Äòperformance‚Äô package [20, 21]).We illustrated the fixed effects by plotting adjusted probabilities (‚Äòggeffects‚Äô and ‚Äòggplot2‚Äô packages [22, 23]).

sec.title: Missing data
sec.p: As routinely collected data were used, we had no ability to detect if there were missing outcome data. When comparing demographic characteristics of arms at baseline we used complete‚Äêcase analysis, as demographic data could be missing.

sec.title: Aboriginal involvement and consent
sec.p: Study methods were designed in consultation with two umbrella Aboriginal community‚Äêcontrolled health organizations (Supporting information, Table¬†S2). The participating ACCHS were involved in refining study design. ACCHS‚Äô custodianship of study data was recognized: consent to participation and data release was sought from each ACCHS from authorized representatives and the board; ACCHS were provided with the results and the manuscript for comment before submitting for publication.

sec.title: Ethics statement
sec.p: This study received approval from eight ethics committees in Australian states where the participating services were located (Supporting information, Table¬†S2). Three were Aboriginal‚Äêspecific committees.

sec.title: Description of sample
sec.p: The 22 ACCHS contributed 83‚Äâ032 client records between 29 August 2016 and 15 August 2019 (Fig.¬†2, Supporting information, Table¬†S6). From January 2019, one waiting‚Äêlist control service was unable to provide data due to change in practice software. Gender was missing for six clients. Service and client characteristics at baseline (Table¬†1) and at the end of the study (Supporting information, Table¬†S6) show that sample composition remained broadly unchanged.

caption.p: Flow diagram of participating services (n‚Äâ=‚Äânumber of services). aOne service was unable to provide data from January 2019 onwards as they stopped using Communicare to log AUDIT‚ÄêC results. Duration of follow‚Äêup was 24‚Äâmonths

sec.title: Outcomes
sec.p: The odds of screening at baseline were lower for the early support arm than waiting‚Äêlist controls. The odds of recorded BI and any treatment were negligible in both arms. Unadjusted smoothed rates by service and trial arm (Supporting information, Figs S1‚ÄìS3) and adjusted ICCs (Table¬†2) demonstrate great variability in effects among the services. Detailed fixed effects results are presented in Table¬†2.

fn.p: Intervention‚Äâ=‚Äâeffect of the entire 24‚Äêmonth support model given by the interaction between condition and post‚Äêimplementation time‚Äêperiod. This interaction represents relative change in the odds for the early support arm when compared to the waiting‚Äêlist control arm, post‚Äêimplementation. ICC‚Äâ=‚Äâintracluster correlation coefficient; OR‚Äâ=‚Äâodds ratio; CI‚Äâ=‚Äâconfidence interval; SE‚Äâ=‚Äâstandard error.

sec.title: AUDIT‚ÄêC screening
sec.p: After implementation, the odds of screening increased in both arms, but the increase within the early support arm was much larger (simple slope: OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ40.48, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ17.82‚Äì91.97). This resulted in early support increase in odds nearly eight times greater (OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ7.95, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ4.04‚Äì15.63, P‚Äâ<‚Äâ0.001) than controls. Probabilities of AUDIT‚ÄêC screening adjusted for the effects of the support model are shown in Fig.¬†3.

caption.p: Predicted probabilities of screening in the early and waiting‚Äêlist control arms at baseline and during 24‚Äâmonths of implementation

sec.title: Any treatment and BI
sec.p: We found no clear evidence that the support model increased in the odds of having any treatment recorded in the early support arm (simple slope: OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.12 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.74‚Äì1.68). However, odds reduced significantly for waiting‚Äêlist controls (OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.59, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.41‚Äì0.85, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.01). The reduction resulted in significantly greater odds of any treatment in early support services (OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.89, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.19‚Äì2.98, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.01) than in controls.

The evidence that the model increased the odds of BI in the early support arm post‚Äêimplementation was inconclusive (simple slope: OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.71, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.52‚Äì5.56), as was the evidence for the early support arm's increase in odds when compared to waiting‚Äêlist controls (OR‚Äâ=‚Äâ1.95, 95% CI‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.53‚Äì7.17, P‚Äâ=‚Äâ0.32).
However, adjusted probabilities for both any‚Äêtreatment and BI remained extremely low (Figs¬†4 and 5).

caption.p: Predicted probabilities of receiving any treatment in the early and waiting‚Äêlist control arms at baseline and during 24‚Äâmonths of implementation
Predicted probabilities of receiving brief intervention in the early and waiting‚Äêlist control arms at baseline and during 24‚Äâmonths of implementation

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This support model resulted in increased AUDIT‚ÄêC screening over the 24‚Äâmonths of support and a higher likelihood of screening than during the 12‚Äêmonth active support phase [9]. However, the high variability in improvement between services [9] persisted until the end of implementation. Given this variability, and the lower baseline screening rates in early support arm, these results must be viewed with caution.
Consistent with the results during 12‚Äêmonth active phase [9], we were not able to show clear evidence that the support model improved the BI rates over 24‚Äâmonths.

The significant change in odds of any treatment in early support services when compared to waiting‚Äêlist controls was driven mainly by a reduction of recorded treatment provision in controls. This result may indicate that the support prevented a drop‚Äêoff in treatment provision in the early support arm. However, as the probability of treatment remained extremely low, the increase does not translate to a clinically meaningful result.

Alcohol consumption varies within and between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities [24]. The design of our model employed tailoring to local conditions, iterative support and using data to drive improvement. Longer duration of implementation (24‚Äâmonths) contrasted with past implementation studies where sites received support over 28‚Äâweeks on average [13]. These features may have made it possible for many services to implement improvements despite their highly variable context, ranging from settings where alcohol was freely available to others, where individuals had to drink outside the community.

sec.title: Recommendations for policy, practice and research
sec.p: The low implementation rates and high variability in effect sizes indicate that further effort is needed to see more consistent improvements in implementation. At service level, this might include periodic training for new and continuing staff involved in alcohol care and training, on how to improve and monitor service quality (e.g. continuous quality improvement). Screening in combination with other risk factors [e.g. using SNAP (smoking, nutrition, alcohol and physical activity)] may improve client acceptability [25]. Ensuring that practice software prompts recording of BI in response to a raised AUDIT‚ÄêC score may help to raise treatment rates.

Previous studies have shown that multiple organizational levels need to be involved to optimize health service improvement efforts [7, 26, 27]. Furthermore, the ACCHS' work to sustainably improve Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health must be supported by both state and federal government. Efforts are needed to address systems‚Äêlevel barriers such as inconsistent, inadequate or siloed funding [28].

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The pragmatic setting of this implementation trial made the study vulnerable to factors beyond our control. Most significantly, introduction of AUDIT‚ÄêC as a national key performance indicator for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander primary care in June 2017 [29] may have made early support services more receptive to the support. The effect of this policy change is reflected in the increased odds of screening post‚Äêimplementation in both arms.

At service level recording of BI was unlikely to be consistent across sites, as clinicians had to search for and select the relevant clinical item in practice software. Some practices recorded counselling for alcohol by their specialized drug and alcohol staff in different software.

Resource constraints limited our ability to investigate the effect of individual components of the model on outcomes and to capture contextual information (e.g. how support components were used locally to achieve improvement) [26].

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: We have demonstrated that our flexible model of support, provided over 24‚Äâmonths, can result in improvement of AUDIT‚ÄêC screening. Variability in outcomes indicate that the model was not uniformly successful in inducing gains in screening. Effects on treatment rates for unhealthy alcohol use are less clear. The longer duration of support facilitated successful delivery of the support model at all sites and appeared to be a factor in improving outcomes. Our study suggests that multi‚Äêfaceted implementation strategies, which include data‚Äêdriven tailoring as well as iterative monitoring and improvement processes, are well suited to the needs of ACCHS because of their flexibility and adaptability to local contexts.

sec.title: DECLARATION OF INTERESTS
sec.p: None.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: This work was supported by the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) through a Project Grant (ID#1105339), the Centre of Research Excellence in Indigenous Health and Alcohol (ID# 1117198) and Practitioner Fellowships (K.C., ID#1117582; P.H., MRFF ID#1155320). The funder had no role in the study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript. We would like to acknowledge all investigators, staff, students and members of the Centre of Research Excellence Indigenous Health and Alcohol who contributed to this study. In particular, the involvement of: Kristie Harrison (Wiradjuri)‚Äîservice recruitment, national workshops and on‚Äêsite training; Jimmy Perry (Ngarrindjerri, Arrernte), Rob Assan and Peter Jack‚Äînational workshops; Taleah Reynolds (Anaiwan), Teagan Weatherall (Kamilaroi, Anaiwan) and Summer Loggins (Bunjalung, Gadigal)‚Äîresearch assistance; Dr Jos√© Padarian‚Äîtechnical input; and the 22 ACCHS for participation and their contribution to the study design.
